definition: How close your measurements are to the true/actual value.
Silver - Derived from the Latin word 'Argentum'.
The smallest/basic structural unit of an element that retains all of its physical and chemical properties.
Gold - Derived from the Latin word 'Aurum'.
1 Calorie (Cal) = 1000 calories (cal); 1 cal = 4.184 Joules (J).
A substance that speeds up a chemical reaction without itself being used up.
Changes that result in the formation of new substances; the chemical composition changes. Example: 2H₂ + O₂ → 2H₂O.
Properties that can be observed by performing a chemical reaction, changing the substance's chemical composition (e.g., flammability).
Substances formed when two or more elements are chemically bonded together in a simple whole-number ratio. Examples: H₂O (water) and NaCl (table salt). Each element does not retain its own identity.
Copper - Derived from the Latin word 'Cuprum'.
Elements that exist as molecules consisting of two atoms. These include H₂, N₂, O₂, F₂, Cl₂, Br₂, and I₂ (forms a '7' shape on the periodic table).
The simplest form of matter that retains all of its physical and chemical properties. They consist of only one type of atom. Examples: oxygen (O), hydrogen (H), and iron (Fe).
A pure compound with the chemical formula C₂H₅OH, commonly found in alcoholic beverages.
The ability to do work.
Properties that depend on the amount of substance (e.g., mass, volume).
Iron - Derived from the Latin word 'Ferrum'.
Different types of energy, including kinetic, potential, thermal, chemical, electrical, nuclear, and radiant energy.
Mercury - Derived from the Latin word 'Hydrargyrum'.
A mixture that is uniform throughout, such as a saltwater solution or air.
A mixture where the components are not evenly distributed, like oil and water or a salad.
Properties that are independent of the amount of substance (e.g., density, temperature, specific gravity).
A pure substance, chemically known as C₃H₈O, often used as a disinfectant or cleaning agent.
Potassium - Derived from the Latin word 'Kalium'.
½ × mass × velocity² (½ mv²).
Energy can neither be created nor destroyed; it only changes form.
Anything that has mass and occupies space. It can be classified as either a pure substance or a mixture.
A physical combination of two or more substances where each retains its own identity. Examples include paint or sand and water.
Sodium - Derived from the Latin word 'Natrium'.
A pure substance, often stored as O₂ in medical settings.
A mixture consisting of various compounds, often including pigments, solvents, and binders.
Lead - Derived from the Latin word 'Plumbum'.
Changes in appearance without changing the chemical composition of the substance (e.g., snow melting, evaporation, condensation).
Properties that can be observed or measured without changing the chemical composition of the substance (e.g., color, odor).
Mass × gravitational acceleration × height (mgh).
How close your measurements are to each other.
Made up of only one component and can be classified as either elements or compounds. Examples include gold (Au) and water (H₂O).
Antimony - Derived from the Latin word 'Stibium'.
Just states fact.
Explains the fact.
A systematic approach to solving problems.
Tin - Derived from the Latin word 'Stannum'.
Density of the substance divided by the density of water (unitless).
The different forms in which matter can exist, which include gases, liquids, solids, and plasma.
Everything around the system.
The part of the universe being studied, such as the contents of a test tube or flask.
Tungsten - Derived from the German word 'Wolfram'.
Mass × gravitational acceleration.
Mass divided by volume (mass/volume).
